General course objectives:
General course objectives
This course covers the fundamentals of constitutive laws for the representation of geomaterials, for prediction of the stability of geotechnical structures (foundations, tunnels, slopes, etc.).

The primary objective of this course is to provide students with a general background in soil/rock plasticity as an introduction to the broad area of inelastic response of geomaterials, as well as to provide the framework in which constitutive models are formulated and executed in numerical simulations.

Students who complete the course will be capable of formulating numerical models and analyse geotechnical problems with the use of numerical methods.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Understand how the general stress-strain response of the soil is represented mathematically.
Understand how constitutive laws are implemented numerically.
Calibrate parameters for various constitutive models.
Predict stress strain response under given strain path and stress path conditions (drained and undrained).
Understand the advantages and limitations of each constitutive framework and models, with respect to specific geotechnical problems.
Predict the capacity for various geotechnical problems using numerical analysis.
Utilize the mobilized strength design approach.
Report and synthesize the results of numerical analysis
Content: Stress and strain, Elasticity, Hyperelasticity, Soil yielding and plastic flow, Critical state models and Cam-Clay, Combined isotropic-kinematic hardening,
